claims.claim: Incarceration education programs often fail to result in degrees, leaving participants with credits but no diploma.
claims.quote: the system often abuses things like that. And so they had a bunch of people going to class and they weren't walking out with degrees. They were walking around about out with a bunch of credits...

claims.claim: Formerly incarcerated individuals face high barriers to funding their education post-release.
claims.quote: I had to find a way to fund it. On my own, which is very difficult. You have to find organizations that will, I mean, schools that will work with you, where the credits will be transferable...

claims.claim: The cost of new textbooks for courses is prohibitively expensive for formerly incarcerated students.
claims.quote: The system requires you to buy brand new books every time so you can't get used books. So, a lot of my books were $350 to, to do the actual class.

claims.claim: Access to education changes the self-perception of incarcerated individuals from prisoners to students.
claims.quote: People approach things differently. I mean, if you approach your incarceration as being a prisoner, that's what you're going to become if you get to approach it by being a student. That's what you become.

claims.claim: Educational programs in prison should be aligned with realistic post-release opportunities.
claims.quote: a lot of the degrees they do are entrepreneurial degrees. Those are nice in theory, except for one of your conditions of parole, is you must work for somebody else.

claims.claim: Peer-led reentry programs could enable formerly incarcerated individuals to pursue meaningful careers.
claims.quote: if we create situations where we've got peer led reentry and things like that, people can get degrees and go into fields that they actually want to do and they're actually motivated to do.
